bioghist.p: David Weiss was born in Philadelphia and graduated from Temple University before embarking on a literary career which has produced a number of successful historical novels. Weiss' novel, Naked Came I, has been published in 13 editions and 25 languages. Weiss also wrote fictional biographies of Mozart, Isadora Duncan, and Christopher Wren. For a dozen years Weiss collaborated with David O. Selznick on screen treatments. A Philadelphia native, Stymean Karlen moved to New York in the 1930s where her plays For This Relief Much Thanks and The Eleventh Commandment brought her to the attention of Cheryl Crawford (The Group Theater), Clifford Odets, and John Gassner. With their encouragement and support she enrolled in The Group Theater, shared an American Theater Play Contest selection with Langston Hughes, and was awarded a Rockefeller Grant for writing. Her interest eventually turned more to painting and poetry, interests she combined in creating over 2000 "portrait poems." She successfully held exhibitions in New York, Los Angeles, La Jolla among other centers. Her poetry was published in Voices, The Yale Poetry Review, Beloit Journal, The Westminster Review, and Poetry among others, as was also an essential part of many of the historical novels of her husband, David Weiss. Karlen and Weiss were married for 53 years.

scopecontent.p: David Weiss materials include extensive typescripts of manuscripts by Weiss, some heavily annotated. Manuscripts include Tender Loving Care, I, Rembrandt, Guilt Maker, Sacred and Profane, Forever & After, Juliet's War, Picasso, Letters to the World, Isadora Duncan, the Loves of Alma Maria. The collection also includes: notes for his Mozart novels; galley proofs, typed lists of corrections, and author's comments; correspondence with publishers and agents, often with reader's comments on the works; personal correspondence, including several letters from Anthony Quinn; financial and legal records, including royalty statements, contracts, and story options; clippings of reviews and advertisements for Weiss's books; and reader's reports by Weiss and others for the Selznick Co. Stymean Karlen materials include: numerous illustrated "portrait poems" on paper and Bainbridge board; paintings on board in wood frames; typescripts of plays, poems, and novels; and a small number of letters from staff at Temple University Special Collections about the receipt of donated papers and the online exhibit of Karlen's artwork. The collection also includes a plaster bust, possibly of David Weiss or his father.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
